A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.

An algebraic subset of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) is the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\) of the polynomials belonging to a subset \(E\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\). It is denoted as \(V(E)\).
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Algebraic subset to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of an Algebraic subset involves the concept of a polynomial ring, specifically mentioned as 'K[X]=K[X_1, ..., X_n]'. A polynomial ring is a type of ring, which is defined by the operations of addition and multiplication that satisfy certain properties such as associativity, distributivity, and the existence of a unit element. These properties are essential characteristics of a ring, as defined in the provided definition of a ring. Therefore, understanding and defining a polynomial ring inherently requires the concept of a ring. Since the definition of an Algebraic subset relies on the concept of a polynomial ring, the concept of a ring must be defined and understood first to make sense of what an Algebraic subset is. Thus, the concept of a ring is necessary for the definition of an Algebraic subset to be meaningful and complete.
